title: Bush Heritage R workshops
text:
Hi all, we’re very much looking forward to our 3 days of R’ing with you.
In preparation, please install R, RStudio, and the following R packages. You can just copy and paste the code below into the console of RStudio and hit enter.

Day 1 - Data wrangling and visualisation in R

install.packages(c("tidyverse"))



Day 2 & 3 - Statistical Modelling in R

install.packages('ggplot2', 'patchwork', 'DHARMa', 'MASS', 'Hmsc', 'tmap', 'sf', 'terra', 'tidyr', 'vegan', 'dplyr', 'ggcorrplot', 'fields')

Cheers,
Christina, Caitie and Jackson

title: About Us
text: Dr Christina Buelow is a quantitative ecologist who loves data and models. She got her start as a field ecologist, but these days she spends most of her time behind a computer developing models and tools to solve challenging problems related to conservation and sustainable use of Earth’s ecosystems. Currently, she is working closely with international NGOs to inform climate-smart conservation of coastal ecosystems. Although the website is still under construction, you can find out more about her work here.

title: Further Resources
text:
Writing code is 80% googling the answer (unattributed)

If you are going to be a successful R user, then you need to get good at finding help to deal with bugs. The above aphorism is widely subscribed to by professional programmers. R is no exception. If you web search an issue, like ‘ggplot remove legend’ you will commonly get a pretty decent answer on Stack Overflow or a similar site. We probably used google hundreds of times to write the course notes.
If the answer doesn’t already exist there then sign up to Stack Overflow and ask it yourself (but spend a bit of time looking, no one wants to get tagged for duplicating an existing question!).
Another good idea is to find a local support group. R coding is an emotional experience, frustration is a common one, but the elation of finding a solution can help us persist. Having other people to help, or even just listen to your frustrations is a huge help for your motivation to keep learning R.
Remember to always put together a reprex before you ask for help!
There are plenty of good books out there (too many to choose from in fact). Some good resources are:



R for Data Science, for data wrangling mainly
Advanced R as a follow on for R for Data Science





R Graphics Cookbook, for ggplot and free on the web





Chris often refers to Mixed Effects Models and Extensions in Ecology with R
The classic text for GAMs is Generalized Additive Models: An Introduction with R. This has a very technical treatment of GAMs, but also an extensive section with practical examples, including spatial ones.





Geocomputation in R
Spatial Data Science with Applications in R
Spatial Data Science, for sf, tmap, stars, and more
Spatial Data Science, for terra
Spatial Statistics for Data Science, for spatial statistics
If you are interested in interactive web-based mapping Christina has put together a great tutorial which is based on Leaflet for R.





If you want to learn new tricks, or stay up-to-date with the latest packages, the blog aggregator R-Bloggers has a non-step feed of R blogs from all over the world and all disciplines, including our colleague Chris Brown, one of the former instructors in this course.

If you prefer to have a printed guide, another tactic is to web search your favourite package and ‘cheatsheet’.
